text: yeah hi everyone Anthony Banton oh here
the Internet's busiest music nerd and it
is time for a review of the new puppy
album I disagree this is a new album
from singer-songwriter multimedia artist
poppy who has had a very odd and
dramatic creative trajectory over the
past five years or so going from
unsettling internet cult meme to grimes
collaborator and iconic figure on
Diplo's Mad Decent and if you don't
understand how weird that progression is
I encourage you to do a bit of a binge
of Poppy's YouTube video catalog and you
will get what I mean
poppy is still evolving though
creatively and her new record here might
be her boldest metamorphosis yet
completely embracing the sounds of Ault
metal new metal industrial and a lot
more now if I was naive I would chalk
this change up to simply thinking hey
these metal tracks from my last record
did really well so I'm gonna hightail it
with the producers of those songs to a
metal label and we're just gonna like do
a metal record but it also runs deeper
than that because this change also
coincides with a split with Poppy's
longtime collaborator Titanic Sinclair
someone who'd arguably been pivotal in
forging the poppy image and character he
even is credited on numerous songs from
this LP but despite working with Titanic
for years and even taking his side in
the highly publicized lawsuit from his
former collaborator Mars Argo who was
essentially poppy before there was a
poppy she has now changed her tune on
Titanic in a recent statement and in a
way is now confirming these allegations
of manipulation leveled by Argo with her
original lawsuit look it's all very
messy but still worth going over because
it's all out there in the public already
and all this is certainly going to mean
a sea change for poppy going forward
this new album certainly already sounds
like it like I said earlier I disagree
is poppy working with two of the most
bombastic producers from her last record
and making a mostly metal album honestly
it's a really refreshing change of pace
not just for poppy but also for any pop
our
is generally to be grabbing and
refurbishing these types of metal risks
that have mostly gone out with mm the
whole record is relatively short at 35
minutes 10 tracks but it packs a lot of
punch and that confined amount of time
now even though this new metal angle for
poppy might look really dark and edgy
and mean on the surface the opening
track concrete goes to show just how
much fun poppy and her collaborators are
trying to have on this one within the
first minute of the track we get this
transition from sequence drums Sirens
refrains of bury me 6 feet deep to
explosions of grinding syncopated rifts
and drums fluttering guitar harmonies
what sounds like very cutesy j-rock with
references to tasty treats a metalcore
breakdown a somewhat faith know Moorish
transition and then a passage of sunny
vintage pop music that sounds very Beach
Boys esque there's even more to the
track after that even the weird
inclusion of some bad fake crowd
chanting poppy poppy which makes little
to no sense but ok
overall this song is kind of gimmicky
and outright absurd but the transitions
are still really impressive and I like
how the cut really eliminates any
perception that this album would be
taking itself too seriously poppy is
clearly in it for the camp which is
totally fine as long as the songs are
good by comparison the title track here
is a lot more coherent not trying to be
as lol random I genuinely love the dark
and bacey beat that kicks the entire
thing off definitely some industrial
undertones to it especially with the
freakish guitars that orbit the rhythm
here also loving how all this
transitions into an incredibly
triumphant chorus topped with
apocalyptic lyrics of it all burning
down being safe and sound the vocal
harmonies are also better than what I
would have expected given Poppy's last
record we also have be much edgy err
blood money which sounds like a dubstep
drop for people who are still buying
Ozzfest tickets plus the song is packed
with these unsettling refrains of keep
telling yourself that you've been
playing nice and go paper but get this
vibe Jesus that guys it's
almost like a weird Yoko Ono moment on
the record respect to Yoko Ono though
don't get it twisted there's also a
lyric later in the track that really
stood out to me never forget the
excessive a man because the grabbing
hands always grab what they can I'm not
sure who poppy has in mind on this track
but it is interesting to hear her
writing from a place of such
confrontation where someone or something
is really the object of her anger on a
song the lyrics generally across the
record though are still pretty cryptic
but give away just enough to where
you're wondering if she's making some
kind of meta-commentary about drama
surrounding poppy there are definitely
some obvious references to a few things
on anything like me we're at least being
viewed through the context surrounding
this record there are lines that read
like they're about the press
reacting to Argo the comparisons of
poppy to Argo and I would even argue
that the hook might be even about being
possessed by the character of poppy or
maybe personally losing that sense of
where you start in the character ends
without a doubt the messaging on this
one is really curious but ultimately
it's the sinister shouts the Marilyn
Manson s riffs and the chilling keyboard
passages that sell the whole thing the
song rage is hard and sounds like you're
going absolutely manic because you are
trapped in your own personal hell after
a cute little intro featuring some
throbbing electronics and twangy lead
guitars the song fill the crown
instantly transitions into a funny break
beat and then these massive chugging
riffs that sound like they're straight
off of a Rammstein classic I'd say the
guitar tone is almost identical there's
even a strangely familiar background
vocal on the track that I can't say as
Marilyn Manson it may just be someone
who is ripping off Marilyn Manson his
very throaty moans and high-pitched
screams personally I've been listening
to Manson since I was a teenager and if
this is not him it's a really really
really good impersonator we then get the
song nothing I need in the tracklist
here which is a sudden change of pace in
that it's not a metal track instead it's
an ethereal it'll pop cut with a head
bobbing beat just imagine if Radiohead's
all I need
had like a positive outlook on life or
if we had kero kero bonito making dream
pop with a light vapor wave twist the
absolutely insane beats on sit-stay are
pretty much in homage to The Prodigy but
like every track here it is a multi
genre banger where you're not just
getting one sadder influence for too
long of course there is a point where we
do hit some heavier guitars some chunky
trebly bass riffs all of which sounds
like maybe it's in an odd time I'm not
sure it's very oddly shaped groove the
lyrics do get a little repetitive on
bite your teeth but it's still one of
the stranger and more fun songs here
with its jump the [ __ ] up riffs and mr.
bungle ish transitions into these
somewhat tongue-in-cheek guitar leads
the more melodic passages that come
after this are very pretty to the track
sick of the Sun is fine but if we're
gonna transition once more away from
doing a metal track I don't know why we
needed another dreamy cut here even if
this one does have more of a rock angle
and the closing track don't go outside
is easily the longest one here at six
minutes and even though poppy and her
collaborators could have packed a
million breakneck changes into this
thing instead they use this extra time
to build up something a bit more
cinematic a climactic finish with a few
glam rock embellishments here and there
what sort of lingers with me at the end
of the track though is the closing
message of you can be anyone that you
want to be which i think is an
interesting take for someone who has
built a career being this character and
though on this record poppy is in
character I can't help but shake the
feeling that on a lot of tracks here she
is trying to get through a genuine a
personal and an authentic message about
her mindset through the eyes of this
character there were a few tracks here
that struck me as being a little bogged
down in their own novelty or just
generally being okay a little
underwhelming but most of the songs here
make for a pretty awesome multifaceted
thrill ride though I do wonder how far
poppy will be able to take this metal
thing I mean I expect at some point in
the future she will move on to something
else but we could be looking at
something that could really just be the
tip of the ice
berg of some long extended series of
albums that go even deeper into this
style not sure but either way hopefully
what papi drums up in the future is
interesting as well I'm feeling a light
too decent eight on this one transition
